Award.AwardTitle: Methods for Defect Manipulation in Semiconducting Oxides
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: The technologically useful properties of a ceramic material often depend upon the atomic defects contained in its crystalline structure. The present work seeks to further develop methods to control the concentration and movement of atomic defects in semiconducting ceramics such as titanium dioxide and zinc oxide. The methods are based upon manipulation of chemical bonds at the material surface or illumination by ultraviolet light. Control via these methods opens new possibilities for manipulating oxide defects in numerous applications. As specific examples, such control improves the properties of titanium dioxide as a photocatalyst for environmental water remediation and hydrogen production for renewable energy by water splitting, and as a component of catalysts for a wide variety of high-volume chemical production processes. The use of defect-manipulated catalysts to accelerate chemical reactions and to provide routes to new chemical products could further strengthen the competitive edge of the US chemical industry. Uses for high quality zinc oxide include transparent conducting electrodes for solar cells to produce renewable energy, and inexpensive green-blue optical emitters for consumer electronic devices.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: This research project uses a combination of experiments and computations to quantify and model the mechanisms for surface-based defect manipulation in single-crystal titanium dioxide and zinc oxide, and to exploit those discoveries more fully in the synthesis of defect-engineered polycrystalline titanium dioxide for thin-film applications. Experiments with single crystals focus upon the measurement of oxygen diffusion as a marker for atomic defect behavior. Parallel experiments on thin films involve carefully controlled deposition of titanium dioxide by atomic layer techniques, followed by heating in controlled atmospheres of specific chemical composition, in some cases under ultraviolet photostimulation. Computations that support all this work entail refinement of a mathematical simulator software package for modeling defect behavior in titanium dioxide and zinc oxide based upon both experimental findings as well as quantum calculations that give atomic-scale insights. In addition to a graduate student, a substantial number of undergraduate researchers are involved directly in the research, providing important skills training in materials synthesis and characterization as well as chemical reaction measurements. This research is taking place in parallel with development of an industry-supported laboratory course for upper-division undergraduates and graduate students called "Chemistry and Transport in Semiconductor Materials Synthesis." In addition, several activities to promote the importance of ethics in science and engineering are being pursued.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The technologically useful properties of a solid often depend upon defects it contains within the regular ordering of its atoms. Examples of such defects include vacancies (missing atoms) and interstitial (extra) atoms that wedge into the regular order. Despite the harmful sound of "defects," their presence can sometimes be essential to the operation of devices based on semiconductors. The ability to control the type, concentration, and spatial distribution of such defects is important for practical applications. For example, silicon-based integrated circuits rely upon defects such as vacancies and interstitials to aid the diffusion of dopant atoms that is necessary for device fabrication. Defects in ceramic semiconducting oxides such as titanium dioxide and zinc oxide affect the performance of ultraviolet lasers and blue-green light emitters, the effectiveness of catalysts and photocatalysts for environmental and energy applications, the sensitivity of solid-state electrolyte sensors, the efficiency of devices for converting sunlight to electrical power, the electrical transmission of transparent conductors for solar cells, and the magnetic properties of spintronic devices.

Work under this grant further developed defect manipulation techniques that exploit the presence of nearby surfaces, and focused upon the ceramic semiconducting oxides titanium dioxide and zinc oxide. The interaction of surfaces with defects exhibits rich and complicated chemistry.  Until now, little attention has been paid to this form of surface chemistry, even though it plays a primary role in regulating bulk defect concentrations in confined geometries such as thin films, small particles and nanowires. The work employed a combination of experiments and computations to better quantify and model the mechanisms for surface-based defect manipulation, and to exploit those discoveries more fully in the synthesis of titanium dioxide for applications involving thin films. Some experiments measured the diffusion rates oxygen within the solids as an indirect probe of defect behavior. Allied computations modeled the motion and reaction of various kinds of defects within the solids to infer their behavior. Other calculations based upon quantum mechanics offered an atomic-scale picture of that behavior. A related set of experiments involved synthesizing thin films of titanium dioxide capable of catalyzing chemical reactions using sunlight, manipulating the defects, and measuring the improvement in chemical reaction rate.   

Several especially noteworthy findings emerged from this work.

  • With suitably prepared surfaces, the population of oxygen-related defects in both titanium dioxide and zinc oxide shifts from vacancies to interstitial atoms.  In zinc oxide, this shift is so profound that it actually changes the color of the material. From a technological perspective, the elimination of the vacancies helps to eliminate a significant cause of inefficiency in ultraviolet lasers based upon zinc oxide.
  • The population shifts result entirely from the high rate at which the surfaces create oxygen interstitial atoms.  This creation rate can be controlled to a significant degree by placing very small quantities of a chemical element like sulfur on the surface.  The physical mechanisms explaining why this approach works were discovered using quantum calculations.
  • The effectiveness of titanium catalysts using sunlight to run reactions can be increased by up to a factor of ten using defect manipulation techniques at the surface.

The research findings showcase new possibilities for manipulating oxide defects in the applications indicated above, and intellectual property emerged from the work. As part of the research, a sizable number of undergraduate, master-level, and doctoral-level students received training in advanced material synthesis and characterization techniques. Several of these students came from groups underrepresented in science and engineering. Also, suitable research results were incorporated into university courses on microelectronics processing and chemical reactor analysis.  In addition, several activities to promote the importance of ethics in science and engineering were pursued.
